Articles.Content: Can someone explain what the purpose of SpaceY's Interstage Adapters are?  The description says for use to make engine clusters, but it only gives me the option to put one engine on it.  Can someone else please?  Thanks.

1 hour ago, Armor9 said:

Can someone explain what the purpose of SpaceY's Interstage Adapters are?  The description says for use to make engine clusters, but it only gives me the option to put one engine on it.  Can someone else please?  Thanks. 

Oh man, those things are the neatest thing since sliced bread.  I love them.  Wish they were stock.

Here's the deal:

In stock KSP, you have different sizes of part stacks.  You can have a 1.25m stack, for example.  Or a 2.5m stack.  Generally all the components in the stack have to be the same size.

Well, not have to be... but you generally want them to be.  (Other than the case of using a conical adapter to put a small stack on top of a big one.)  For example, you wouldn't want to have a 2.5m fuel tank, and then a 1.25m engine on top of it with another 2.5m tank on top of that.  It would be a bad design, for two reasons.  First, it would be very bendy to have that narrow wasp-waist in the middle of the rocket-- the darn thing would flop all over the place during launch.  Second, it would be horribly un-aerodynamic; you want to be smooth cylinders.

But what if you want to put a 1.25m engine in the middle of a 2.5m stack?

Or, for that matter... what if you wanted to put a cluster of smaller engines in the middle of a bigger-diameter stack?  In KSP, this Cannot Be Done, because of the tree nature of rockets; you can't have a big tank with a bunch of little engines under it, and then have another big tank under that one that all of the engines are attached to.  Even if you somehow fake up an engine cluster with surface attachment, you'd still only be able to attach the tank below to just one of the engines, which would be, again, very floppy and horribly draggy.

This is what the interstage adapters are for.

Each one of them has two attachment points:  a big-diameter one located fairly far below the plate, which is the same diameter as the plate; and a single smaller one, or cluster of smaller ones, located immediately under the plate.

Thus, let's say you want to put a 1.25m engine in the middle of a 2.5m stack.  You have your 2.5m upper tank, and under that you put an interstage adapter that goes from 2.5m down to 1.25m.  You attach your 1.25m engine to the little 1.25m node that's snugged right up to the bottom of the plate.  And then-- here comes the clever bit-- you attach a 2.5m stack decoupler to the big 2.5m node that's floating in space down below the engine you just attached.  Bam!  As soon as you do that, a cylindrical 2.5m shroud pops up (just like when you have a 2.5m engine in a stack).  You now have a nice smooth cylinder that is rigid and sturdy because the little engine inside isn't actually holding any of the load.

The interstage adapters that have multiple nodes let you make clusters.  For example, there's a 2.5m thruster plate that has a 1.25m node surrounded by eight little 0.625m nodes, or a 3.75m plate that has seven 1.25m nodes in a cluster, and so forth.

It's a brilliantly simple idea that greatly expands the options in rocket design.

(The above explanation would be enormously clearer with some illustrations, but I'm not in front of my KSP computer right now, alas, so no screenshots.)

9 minutes ago, Snark said:

<lots of very good info, as usual>

This is all extremely interesting. I may have to take a closer look at the SpaceY mod. I've never used it myself because I thought it was basically a simple "moar boosters" pack, which in stock KSP I really don't think it's necessary (and in RO/RSS I use procedural parts, so again, not an issue). 

But, if it has fun toys like that (and hopefully others as well) then I might have to give it a try.

12 minutes ago, FullMetalMachinist said:

This is all extremely interesting. I may have to take a closer look at the SpaceY mod. I've never used it myself because I thought it was basically a simple "moar boosters" pack, which in stock KSP I really don't think it's necessary (and in RO/RSS I use procedural parts, so again, not an issue). 

I just love SpaceY.  I would adore it for the interstage adapters alone, even if it had nothing else.

However, I do like that it gives a lot more variety of SRBs, and not just huge ones, either-- it also has a pretty nice set of 0.625m SRBs.  It expands design options quite a bit.

Also, some nice big SpaceX-style landing legs.

Oh!  And sepratron nosecones.  Gawd, I love those things.  They're perfect for putting on top of your radial boosters.  Available in 1.25m and 2.5m sizes, both regular and slanted.

Oh!  And a petal-style conical 3.75m-to-2.5m cargo bay so you can build Apollo-style rockets.

And yes, Really Big Rockets with 5m parts.

First of all, thank you for the in depth reply, it was very helpful.  Perhaps I have no unlocked the right Interstage Adapters yet because the ones I have only have a node far below and then a node just above, but I do not yet have one where I saw multiple nodes to make the clusters.  

Do I have to do anything special to see the multiple nodes?  Maybe that is what I am not doing.  Thoughts? 

Thanks again.

On 4/14/2016 at 5:52 AM, Armor9 said:

First of all, thank you for the in depth reply, it was very helpful.  Perhaps I have no unlocked the right Interstage Adapters yet because the ones I have only have a node far below and then a node just above, but I do not yet have one where I saw multiple nodes to make the clusters.  

Do I have to do anything special to see the multiple nodes?  Maybe that is what I am not doing.  Thoughts? 

Thanks again. 

Nothing special to unlock.  There are a bunch of different interstage adapters in SpaceY.  Some of them just have a single bottom node, some have several.  If you're not seeing the multi-node ones yet, it may just be that you haven't yet unlocked the necessary technology in R&D.

On 4/16/2016 at 3:19 PM, Snark said:

Nothing special to unlock.  There are a bunch of different interstage adapters in SpaceY.  Some of them just have a single bottom node, some have several.  If you're not seeing the multi-node ones yet, it may just be that you haven't yet unlocked the necessary technology in R&D.

Gotcha, thanks. 

Regarding the ones with the single nodes, what is special about them and why would we use one instead of what we have always used?

56 minutes ago, Armor9 said:

Gotcha, thanks. 

Regarding the ones with the single nodes, what is special about them and why would we use one instead of what we have always used? 

There are two ways to attach things in KSP: node attachment, and surface attachment.

Node attachment is when you connect one green ball to another.

Surface attachment is when you take a part that has no node, and still stick it to something else. A battery, or a RCS thruster, or a thermometer... Oh, and when you attach a SRB to a radial decoupler, that's surface attachment too.

However, not all things can be surface attached. To make it work, you need the part you want to attach to support surface attachment, and you also need the part you want to attach to to allow it. Only when both parts allow it, you can surface attach.

The  thing about the interstage adapters with only one single node is that they allow surface attaching. So if you have an engine that supports it, you can attach a large group of engines to that adapter, without using any nodes at all! Mind you, stock KSP's engines are almost all not surface attachable, save for the radial ones. But a lot of modded engines are. Some mods even tweak stock engines to be surface attachable, where it makes sense. Like, why does the Ant engine even need a node? That thing is predestined for clustering, if only Squad would set the flag to enabled

 

 

But even if you don't use surface attachable engines, the single-node interstage can still make sense. For instance, you can build a great Mun lander with a Rockomax X200-8 fuel tank and a Terrier engine. That's a 1.25m engine under a 2.5m tank. On the Mun, it has more than enough thrust. However, if you put that on top of a 2.5m rocket, you have 2.5m nodes all the way through that stack... except where the Terrier attaches to the decoupler below. That's a 1.25m node, which is significantly weaker, but still needs to support heavy 2.5m parts above it. The result is a "wet noodle rocket". Not to mention that it looks super dumb when you suddenly have a gap in the side of your rocket because the Terrier is so much smaller. It causes extra drag too, because of the highly unaerodynamic shape of that gap.

So the interstage adapter lets you attach a Terrier to it... but the 2.5m stack of the rest of the rocket attaches to the 2.5m node of the interstage, not to the Terrier. What you get is a stiff, stable rocket, and the gap around the Terrier is covered by an interstage fairing, which makes the rocket look smooth and ensures good aerodynamics.

Another common use of 1.25m engines under much larger tanks is the LV-N nuclear rocket. People often put it under long stacks of Mk3 fuselages, which are even larger and heavier than 2.5m. Having the much larger, stronger node of the interstage is even more important there!

Finally, you can attach something like a stock bicoupler to the interstage adapter to get multiple attachment nodes inside the interstage, provided that your engines are not too long. Some mods also add things like 1.25m->0.625m multicouplers, which further increases your versatility.

Edited April 17, 2016 by Streetwind
